values:
When someone seems really pissed off, or even if something just seems a bit off, lots of the time that person REALLY wants someone to acknowledge it.  Even if it ends up being something they can/have to work out on their own, avoiding a friend when they are in a serious crisis because you don't want to make it worse, or don't know how to deal with it, is the worst thing you could ever do.  A simple "dude, I've been noticing that you're not yourself lately, is something up?" would probably do a world of good.  Too often, people ignore a situation like this, and it ends up being the isolation that really beats a person down.  The human psyche can withstand almost any pressure when it has the support of intimate relationships, whereas I am convinced that it cannot stand at all without them.  You may think you are helping when you take to the back seat and let your troubled friend coast through their hard times, but you are doing them, and yourself, a horrible disservice.  Chances are, they are wondering why you haven't asked them about it.  

So stop being meek, and don't stop yourself when you have the impulse to ask someone if something is wrong.  Chances are your intuition is correct and your friend will thank you when their recovery from their bad day/week/depressive episode finally swings around.  You'll understand why when you end up feeling the same way at some point in your life.

I've kind of sworn off blogging recently, partially because I've been too busy, but partially because it is gradually dawning on me that teenage (or young adult) blogging is so often a way to avoid living life by "writing about life".

However, I forgot to reflect on the prior year, so I guess I'll do it now.

    Everyone always says that they've grown a lot in any given year, but I think I really did this year.  I think I've experienced some of the best that humanity can offer, and most definitely some of the worst.  I've had my heart broken twice, once by my own doing.  And of course, I took a trip of many miles and am in the process of seeing who I miss, who misses me and what that means.
    This year saw the tail end of a trifecta of dealing with mortality: loss of a friend, loss of a family member, public loss.  Lily was still very much fresh in my mind during the earlier months, and Sunny and James came very soon after.  These experiences haven't just been about my own acknowledgment of mortality, they have also been portals of insight into the depth of human complexity.

I came into writing this feeling like I had so much to say.  Maybe I really wanted someone to say something to.  Who knows.

I'd just like to point out that...

THE RED SOX WON THE FUCKING WORLD SERIES!

And I want to learn how to Riverdance like Papelbon.

Dear Beloved Red Sox,

What the fuck are you doing.  Destroy the fucking Indians and then steamroll over the Rockies.  You've done better under worse conditions.  

Kthnxbai,

Jaime

P.S. Yankees suck.

I now know why Doshisha does not have a high school.  Because all the high school drama and attitude can be imported via the program I'm at here.  Seriously, how the fuck did they find all these people and why do they all act like they are 18?!
I really HATE rude, inconsiderate people.  I don't dislike them, I am not annoyed with them, I HATE them.

1) What are you 5?  "No, you're stupid" is no longer an acceptable part of witty banter when you are 20 years old.  The words "gay" and "faggot" stopped being acceptable insults when middle school ended.  Stop trying to piece together your fat kid angst shattered ego by putting other people down.  It makes people despise you.  It's going to be extremely difficult to spend the mandatory amount of time we have to spend together if you don't wise up.  And yes, there isn't even a question in my mind that I could kick your ass.

2) You really shouldn't still be dating this guy, he's proven himself to be a dragon chasing womanizer.  He's a dragon chasing womanizer that is my friend, but that still doesn't mean that you should date him.  Get out and get out now, you're too hot to waste your time in this way.

3) I need to stop being attracted to you now.  It's pretty clear that you either passive-aggressively hate me with a burning fiery passion for some obvious reason that I don't see, or you are just a crazy bitch.  I really don't want to believe it when people say the latter, but you REALLY have to stop doing that thing you do because it's scary and completely uncalled for.  And if it is called for, for the love of god just TELL ME WHY.

4) Wow...you really don't get it do you?  No one likes you.  You think you're funny and you like to play yourself off as the wounded cynic who makes fun of how stupid everything is, but it isn't working.  Your negativity may just be what sends you home early from this place.  Oh, and it's really funny that you now know my Japanese is FAR better than your own.  Guess it's not healthy to whip out your ego too readily now is it?

5) You are the the umpteenth example of people I am friends with that I really don't know how I'm friends with.  But I'm glad everything worked out in the end owing to the fact that we are both mature (well...maybe not) adults.  Glad you're making your way over here soon and I can't wait to share a drink (or 10) with you and some good friends when you get here.

6) Hoooooly shit.  You surprised me.  You are definitely one of the most hilarious energetic people that I've ever met.  Some people probably won't be able to appreciate it, but don't worry, those of us who can love it.

7) I so often took for granted everything that you did for me when I was younger.  I think I finally figured a lot of it out when you gave me the bracelet at 5AM at Logan.  I still wear it pretty much everyday.  Thanks for everything.  It's nice to know that I have you looking out for me as if I were your own.

8) "Let's get CRUNK" stopped being cool after freshman year.  What you're looking for isn't going to be found at the bottom of the bottle.  Oh, and stop being "AZN."  You are just another whitewashed Asian kid who grew up in the suburbs of a major American city.

9) I want to see you again.  I hate how we left things and how we have to leave things.  I want you here so we can sort this out.  I miss you.

10) I'm not willing to even consider forgiving you until you start admitting that something you did in the past was wrong.  Sorry.  I really want to, but until it feels right, it isn't going to happen.

11) I miss you more than you could possibly imagine.  But I'm also just so mad.  I'm just mad that you didn't call, you didn't email me.  I just wish you would have given me a chance.  I am still thankful everyday for what you gave me.  My life will never be the same because of you and I'm a better for it.  Don't forget about us, because we'll certainly never forget about you.

-No, it isn't just me.
-Yes, she may be a bit crazy.
-No, it isn't just me.
-Maybe I need to stop being friends with people who are more attractive than I am.
-Yes, it rocks.
-A bit of confidence works wonders.
-There need to be more of those that study Japanese.
-There aren't enough to go around.

Sigh...

I'm in Japan.

That is all.

So our little Boston outing kicked all sorts of ass. 

-Met Amanda's friend, who seems like a pretty cool dude. 
-Had dinner at Fire and Ice for the first time in years.  I'm still an awesome cook.
-Bubble tea.  That's all that needs to be said really.
-Connect Four and the world's longest game of Uno at the bubble tea place.
-Karaoke at Uno's where we regaled drunk people with our sultry voices.
-Singing Accent songs on the way home.

I'm going to miss you guys so much...


Oh fine:

- Pick your birth month.
- Strike out anything that doesn't apply to you.
- Bold the five-ten that best apply to you.
- Copy to your own journal, with all twelve months under a lj-cut.
- Tag 12 people from your friends list. (I don't have that many people who will do this...)

Tagged: Allie, Laura, Sarah, Leela

MAY:
Stubborn and hard-hearted. Strong-willed and highly motivated. Sharp thoughts. Easily angered. Attracts others and loves attention. Deep feelings. Beautiful physically and mentally. Firm Standpoint. Needs no motivation. Easily consoled. Systematic (left brain). Loves to dream. Strong clairvoyance. Understanding. Sickness usually in the ear and neck. Good imagination. Good physical. Weak breathing. Loves literature and the arts. Loves traveling. Dislike being at home. Restless. Not having many children. Hardworking. High spirited. Spendthrift.

JANUARY:
Stubborn and hard-hearted. Ambitious and serious. Loves to teach and be taught. Always looking at people's flaws and weaknesses. Likes to criticize. Hardworking and productive. Smart, neat and organized. Sensitive and has deep thoughts. Knows how to make others happy. Quiet unless excited or tensed. Rather reserved. Highly attentive. Resistant to illnesses but prone to colds. Romantic but has difficulties expressing love. Loves children. Loyal. Has great social abilities yet easily jealous. Very stubborn and money cautious.

FEBRUARY:
Abstract thoughts. Loves reality and abstract. Intelligent and clever. Changing personality. Attractive. Sexy. Temperamental. Quiet, shy and humble. Honest and loyal. Determined to reach goals. Loves freedom. Rebellious when restricted. Loves aggressiveness. Too sensitive and easily hurt. Gets angry really easily but does not show it. Dislikes unnecessary things. Loves making friends but rarely shows it. Daring and stubborn. Ambitious. Realizes dreams and hopes. Sharp. Loves entertainment and leisure. Romantic on the inside not outside. Superstitious and ludicrous. Spendthrift. Tries to learn to show emotions.

MARCH:
Attractive personality. Sexy. Affectionate. Shy and reserved. Secretive. Naturally honest, generous and sympathetic. Loves peace and serenity. Sensitive to others. Loves to serve others. Easily angered. Trustworthy. Appreciative and returns kindness. Observant and assesses others. Revengeful. Loves to dream and fantasize. Loves traveling. Loves attention. Hasty decisions in choosing partners. Loves home decors. Musically talented. Loves special things. Moody.

APRIL:
Active and dynamic. Decisive and hasty but tends to regret. Attractive and affectionate to oneself. Strong mentality. Loves attention. Diplomatic. Consoling, friendly and solves people's problems. Brave and fearless. Adventurous. Loving and caring. Suave and generous. Emotional. Aggressive. Hasty. Good memory. Moving. Motivates oneself and others. Sickness usually of the head and chest. Sexy in a way that only their lover can see.

MAY:
Stubborn and hard-hearted. Strong-willed and highly motivated. Sharp thoughts. Easily angered. Attracts others and loves attention. Deep feelings. Beautiful physically and mentally. Firm Standpoint. Needs no motivation. Easily consoled. Systematic (left brain). Loves to dream. Strong clairvoyance. Understanding. Sickness usually in the ear and neck. Good imagination. Good physical. Weak breathing. Loves literature and the arts. Loves traveling. Dislike being at home. Restless. Not having many children. Hardworking. High spirited. Spendthrift.

JUNE:
Thinks far with vision. Easily influenced by kindness. Polite and soft-spoken. Having ideas. Sensitive. Active mind. Hesitating, tends to delay. Choosy and always wants the best. Temperamental. Funny and humorous. Loves to joke. Good debating skills. Talkative. Daydreamer. Friendly. Knows how to make friends. Able to show character. Easily hurt. Prone to getting colds. Loves to dress up. Easily bored. Fussy. Seldom shows emotions. Takes time to recover when hurt. Brand conscious. Executive. Stubborn.

JULY:
Fun to be with. Secretive. Difficult to fathom and to be understood. Quiet unless excited or tensed. Takes pride in oneself. Has reputation. Easily consoled. Honest. Concerned about people's feelings. Tactful. Friendly. Approachable. Emotional temperamental and unpredictable. Moody and easily hurt. Witty and sparkly. Not revengeful. Forgiving but never forgets. Dislikes nonsensical and unnecessary things. Guides others physically and mentally. Sensitive and forms impressions carefully. Caring and loving. Treats others equally. Strong sense of sympathy. Wary and sharp. Judges people through observations. Hardworking. No difficulties in studying. Loves to be alone. Always broods about the past and the old friends. Likes to be quiet. Homely person. Waits for friends. Never looks for friends. Not aggressive unless provoked. Prone to having stomach and dieting problems. Loves to be loved. Easily hurt but takes long to recover.


AUGUST:
Loves to joke. Attractive. Suave and caring. Brave and fearless. Firm and has leadership qualities. Knows how to console others. Too generous and egoistic. Takes high pride in oneself. Thirsty for praises. Extraordinary spirit. Easily angered. Angry when provoked. Easily jealous. Observant. Careful and cautious. Thinks quickly. Independent thoughts. Loves to lead and to be led. Loves to dream. Talented in the arts, music and defense. Sensitive but not petty. Poor resistance against illnesses. Learns to relax. Hasty and trusty. Romantic. Loving and caring. Loves to make friends.

SEPTEMBER:
Suave and compromising. Careful, cautious and organized. Likes to point out people's mistakes. Likes to criticize. Stubborn. Quiet but able to talk well. Calm and cool. Kind and sympathetic. Concerned and detailed. Loyal but not always honest. Does work well. Very confident. Sensitive. Good memory. Clever and knowledgeable. Loves to look for information. Must control oneself when criticizing. Able to motivate oneself. Understanding. Fun to be around. Secretive. Loves leisure and traveling. Hardly shows emotions. Tends to bottle up feelings. Very choosy, especially in relationships. Systematic.

OCTOBER:
Loves to chat. Loves those who loves them. Loves to take things at the center. Inner and physical beauty. Lies but doesn't pretend. Gets angry often. Treats friends importantly. Always making friends. Easily hurt but recovers easily. Daydreamer. Opinionated. Does not care of what others think. Emotional. Decisive. Strong clairvoyance. Loves to travel, the arts and literature. Touchy and easily jealous. Concerned. Loves outdoors. Just and fair. Spendthrift. Easily influenced. Easily loses confidence. Loves children.

NOVEMBER:
Has a lot of ideas. Difficult to fathom. Thinks forward. Unique and brilliant. Extraordinary ideas. Sharp thinking. Fine and strong clairvoyance. Can become good doctors. Dynamic in personality. Secretive. Inquisitive. Knows how to dig secrets. Always thinking. Less talkative but amiable. Brave and generous. Patient. Stubborn and hard-hearted. If there is a will, there is a way. Determined. Never give up. Hardly becomes angry unless provoked. Loves to be alone. Thinks differently from others. Sharp-minded. Motivates oneself. Does not appreciate praises. High-spirited. Well-built and tough. Deep love and emotions. Romantic. Uncertain in relationships. Homely. Hardworking. High abilities. Trustworthy. Honest and keeps secrets. Not able to control emotions. Unpredictable.

DECEMBER:
Loyal and generous. Sexy. Patriotic. Active in games and interactions. Impatient and hasty. Ambitious. Influential in organizations. Fun to be with. Loves to socialize. Loves praises. Loves attention. Loves to be loved. Honest and trustworthy. Not pretending. Short tempered. Changing personality. Not egotistic. Take high pride in oneself. Hates restrictions. Loves to joke. Good sense of humor. Logical.

I am really craving human contact right now.  This place is markedly lacking in people that I want to see.  I still have 9 days left, and they are going to get longer and longer and longer if I don't find people to hang out with.  I've been waking up every morning hoping to be back in my room in Coffrin.  I almost miss Midd dining hall food.  

In other news I got new glasses, some nice dress shirts and a haircut.  I look pretty New York.

As I started to pack I've started to realize how much growth this summer has represented for me.  I've taken in a lot over the last 9 weeks, and not all of it has been Japanese.

Lessons learned, stuff to remember:

-It is possible to explain ridiculous summer camp esque games to people who can in no way communicate with you at all.
-Trying to explain abstract ideas in Japanese without using English is not only hard, it builds character.
-Sometimes, you really ARE reading too much into things and you really ARE taking things too seriously.
-Ping pong is the ultimate escape from all things studying.
-Class at 8 every morning can be enjoyable.
-Japanese people do not cease being fun when they hit middle age.
-Summer in Vermont is atrociously hot.
-Exercise can cure almost any emotional ail.
-You can establish incredible friendships based on very little verbal communication.
-People are not always considerate, but that is because they are people and fundamentally imperfect.
-Muscle mass leaves twice as quickly as it is gained.
-Scary movies can become hilarious with a well placed laugh.  Or 100.
-The definition of contentment is lying in a circle with friends looking up at the stars.
-Japanese people really do love pictures, but only because the only thing they love more is what was going on when they were taken.
-The 21 year old drinking age is completely arbitrary.
-Language barriers can be powerful blocks to human interaction.
-Learning something with the fascination of a child is the best way to approach it.
-Sometimes sentimentality can be cleansing.
-The hurt you feel when you leave people behind means that they were the kind of people worth meeting.

At approximately 9PM tonight, I will be officially allowed to speak English again.  I'm not sure I want to.

It is 5:37, I'm awake with the intent of practicing for my presentation, the last academic obligation I have left, which happens in approximately 3 hours.  After that I will be going on a class picnic where we will be surprising our professors with sets of earrings and four gigantic cards, at which point our professors may (will) weep uncontrollably against the backdrop of Lake Dunmore.  I will then be faced with the task of packing up most of my life into a single cardboard box while doing my last load of laundry, all before our banquet.  At the banquet, I'm helping the karaoke club sing a graduation piece in Japanese, and the language pledge will finally be lifted.  Finally, I will probably attend a party, at which it will be the last time I see a good number of the people I've met here forever.





This has the potential of being an emotional day of epic proportions.

Everything and everyone is pissing me off right now for absolutely no reason at all.  And, for the first time in my life, I think, I'm not going to let it get to me and affect my interactions with people.  Instead, I'm going to put on my running shoes, head out to the hill and run hills for the first time since high school track while listening to music from the movie Ping Pong.




They say that people get mad at people they are about to part from because it makes parting easier.  I'm such a fucking psych major.

I'm not going to lie.  I lost my shit a little bit when the sensei sang us a farewell song in class today.  Ono-sensei actually started crying in earnest and if you don't know this already, crying Japanese females spread tears like the plague.

It's going to be a long sentimental week ahead.

Dear People In My Life,

I hate the word "forever".  In fact, being the nice little Buddhist I am, I'm not a big fan of words that denote us never seeing each other again.  So stop using them, either in English or in Japanese.  Thank you.

-Me




I actually felt sad when I finished my last homework assignment tonight.  Sooooo fucking sabishi right now.  Anyone have a violin?

Um... I'mgoingtoJapaninthreeweeksholyshitI'mgoingtocrapmypantswithexcitement.

I want to see people before I leave for a (gulp) YEAR.

Make it happen folks.  I'll be around from the 20th to the 3rd of September.

So who knew that old Japanese people teaching their native language in the middle of rural Vermont are some of the coolest people ever?  I'm pretty sure I played some 'rut with my Japanese professor last night and I'm pretty sure it was awesome.  Our program director also showed up, slightly red, and joined in our festivities.  

I'm going to miss a lot of people when this is over.

So if I don't get this out I'm going to spontaneously combust, so here goes!

So we had a volleyball game against the Chinese Language School today, and holy shit was it intense.  We lost to their soccer team 11-0 so we went in there with something to prove.  We ended up winning with two of our best players injured and some really shitty (non) observation of the rules by the other team.  But that's not really what I intend to talk about here.

It was horribly irritating to hear people talking shit in my language.  Seriously.  It was amazing how rude the Chinese students were being.  In English, the word "rude" doesn't really carry the same weight as it does in Japanese, which is so frustrating in this context.  I mean they were talking some serious shit, and to be quite honest I was vicariously embarrassed.  I was vicariously embarrassed because my language is being passed on to a generation of people who don't love my culture and don't love the language's origin.  It's being passed onto people who still think it's funny to make "Your mom" jokes in a foreign language.  

The people who are learning Chinese nowadays are mostly people who want to join the CIA and spy on 1.3 billion people, or economically rape the Chinese mainland while spreading global corporate greed.  Wow.  I really just wish I could just make them stop learning my language.  Like just make them quit.  Because it's painful.  It's painful listening to them because their pronunciation sucks monkey testicles, and because I'm aware of the intent behind it.  My language is not yours to use to exploit 1.3 billion people.  And yes, before anyone calls me an elitist, I'm quite comfortable saying that it is MY fucking language.  Until you get your fucking tones right, you don't own an ounce of it.

But at the end of the day we finally shut them up.  It was such an amazing feeling.  Our teacher actually gave me a huge hug as soon as we won the last point and we jumped around in a circle several times like morons but it was worth it.

Yeah,  Nippon.

Good Mexican food, good company, great/traumatic/inappropriate stories.

It's great to be home.

Sometimes people can surprise you, and sometimes a group of misfit, disorganized and completely diverse people can just fit together perfectly.

I feel a little better about being in Japan all of next year.  They have their wings now.  All I have to do is sit back and watch them fly.

I don't like it when friends pull the tacit "I'm going to hang out with my cooler friends" thing.  It's annoying.

In other news, hung out with Allie today and got some uber good sushi.  Not enough to be THAT filling though.  We talked about a cappella (what else) and I forgot the CD she burned me at her house (get it to me at banquet Allie?).

In OTHER news, I almost died just now!  I almost hit a deer in the middle of the road and had to pull some sort of ninja swerve to get out of the way.  It was CRAZY.  I'm alive, though, and the car?  Untouched.  I rock.

Haven't done this in a while.

Ten things to ten people I'd probably never say, but feel completely comfortable saying through the semi anonymity afforded by the internet!

1) I fought battles with my parents and drove farther than I ever have, and I think I did it because of you.  I shouldn't have thought that it would have been any different.  I was, of course, acting like an idiot that Saturday night.  You were right, but that doesn't make it hurt any less.  I'll miss you.

2) I'm glad you finally managed, under the enormous pressure I put forth, to let go of me a little bit.  Worrying about me like that is a sign of love, but if you don't let go slowly, you will be forced to let go all at once, which will be so much more painful, I assure you.  I'm not an adult yet.  I'm not pompous enough to think that of myself.  But, the development of real autonomy requires concessions on the controlling powers that be.  Thanks.

3) You almost killed my confidence in this group.  I'm not going to take it sitting down.  I know I can sing just as well as you can, and I'll do it the way I want, and on my terms.  Someone who I respect far more than you called you the biggest error he's ever made in terms of induction into this group, and it isn't because you aren't talented.  I want to be buddies, but if you don't cut this competitive jock shit out of your personality, that's going to be really hard.

4) Stop being a creepy stalker girl.  If you want to have anything resembling normal interaction with me again, you need to give me some space.  Lots of space.  I'm so glad I'm an ocean away next year.  

5) I hate this stupid a cappella rivalry shit.  You may not have noticed it, but it has been the only point of contention in our friendship.  I'm not sure how to fix it, but it's only going to be worse when we are leading our respective groups.  I never thought that the one thing we both love to do is making things really awkward.

6) Why can't you get it together?  I know it's that time of the year, but come on.  I'm not trying to impose myself on you guys, but I made a HUGE investment of my time and soul into this, and it hurts me when I come back to see a complete lack of commitment.  You have a beautiful thing, but everything takes maintainence and INVESTMENT OF THE SELF.  I want to start coming back because I'm proud that I can sit in and just listen.  Right now, I'm coming back because I feel like I need to.  I'm not trying to relive my glory days, I'm not trying to take over.  I'm just gravely worried.  That's why I'm coming back so often.  I can't do that next year, so please, for pity's sake, get your shit in order.

7) You are so confusing... Make your intentions clear please.

8) Holy crap, I was so frickin' intimidated by you when I first met you.  It turns out that you are a pretty sweet dude after all.  It's a shame we didn't meet earlier.  You may smoke too much, drink too much, and have way too much fun, but somehow you managed to get it all done.  The same cannot be said for a lot of people.  Congrats on becoming a real person, NYC is lucky to have you.

9) Really?  Really... Him?  You can do better.  Do better.

10) I don't know if I'm sorry that this happened or if I'm mad you got off the hook.  I guess we'll never know.  Just know that I'm not afraid of you, nor will I ever be.  Leave the bravado for your stupid football buddies who respect that kind of thing.

This place seems so much emptier than last summer.  Unless some serious shit goes down, I'm going to be one bored kid for the next two weeks.

So if you know me, and I know you, and we like each other, let's get together before I head back to Midd to not speak english for 9 weeks.

Sweet plan?


Yeah.

Written by my cousin, Jennifer Tan:

"My brother's name is Tuan Tan, but for as long as I have been speaking, we have called him Sunny. He was born in Vietnam, my mother's first child. My aunts who remain in the country--and who have not seen him since my mother brought him over to America when he was three years old--remember him as an illuminating, delightful little baby who sassed everybody in perfect Cantonese and Vietnamese. He was beautiful. And for those three years, it was just he and my mom.

He is 29 years old and has been my brother for just a little over 22 of them. Despite this length of time, I've only recently begun to know him, when he finally moved home after rebelling in high school, struggling through two years in college, and moving to New York City with the love of his life. In my memories of him from when I was younger he is shrouded in darkness, a part of this older, cooler universe of which I could only dream of being a part. I remember the attic room, which he shared with Jimmy. He snuck in girls and cigarettes and our first dog, Asia, without my parents knowing. I stole his Miss Saigon, Les Miserable, Wu-Tang cds to record onto casette, because I only had a walkman. Later, he bought me my first cd player and then my first cd, Tragic Kingdom, which he subsequently stole back to give to a girl he liked. He had books and books of drawings, graffitti, and poems, which I would snoop through his things to read. I discovered that he had his heart broken by his first girlfriend in high school. I remember that all of his girlfriends were the prettiest girls I'd ever seen.

He doesn't think that he's ever recovered from that first broken heart. He regrets all of his fuck ups from when he was younger, just like Dad said that he would. He smokes and has a thick Boston accent and drinks too much. He is too creative and brilliant and undisciplined for his own good. He is arguably the most charming, attractive, and intelligent person in our entire three families, and we have always loved him, despite ourselves. I have always been proud to have him as my brother. And he loved us. But the fundamental truth is that he was very, very unhappy. He was tired of failure. He was afraid of being alone. He was afraid of growing old. But he was not afraid of death.

We had all had an awesome ten days, since Jimmy came back. Two weekends ago they came down to Brown for a pig roast with my friends. Last weekend I went home with CJ and Ellen for the Asian New Year. When we were together for the New Year, Sunny pulled me aside and told me, "I hadn't realized how much I missed Jimmy." All of us cousins got together both nights at our house, so I know that in these last few moments, he was happy and surrounded by love. He stayed in from work and drove CJ and I back to school on Monday. Wednesday evening Jimmy left for the airport, back to California, and they never got to say goodbye. Afterwards Sunny made a trip to the drug store for some $30 worth of sleeping pills and alcohol. Thursday morning at around 730am he kissed Kiana goodbye and drove 54 minutes straight up I-93 to New Hampshire, where he checked into a tiny motel room. He was happy and loved. He was happy and loved. That is the final irony. He gave us one last incredible moment together, and then, by 2am Friday morning, he was gone.

I miss him. so much. I am. in pieces. My big beautiful brother. My heart and soul. Oh my god, I miss you so much."

So this is how it went...  This is what I thought it was when I heard about it earlier. 

I saw people from this sector of the family for the first time in years.  There was something so different about them.  Their eyes held an incredible sadness that I had learned to understand this December.  I wonder if it's how I still look now.

I wish it didn't have to be this way.  For Lily.  For Sunny.  I wish someone could have made them understand.

I'm petrified right now.  Stop.  I just want the world to stop.  What the fuck is going on.

What has happened to the world I'm living in?...

It totally just hit me today.



What am I going to do without all these people?

I have no fucking clue...

I turned 20 yesterday. 

How do I have two decades behind me already?

Wisdom (?) of a 20 year old:

  • Drama is often self-inflicted and never worth your time.  People who bring this out in you are also not worth your time.
  • One can meet good friends and say farewell to them within a span of 2 months.  This, however, does not mean that the friendship was not worth it.
  • Life does not stop to observe your loss.  As hard as that is to grapple with in the moment, it is a reality of this world.
  • You can learn a lot from people who are younger than you.
  • Micormanaging life must be done at times, but appreciation of life's small miracles takes little time out of the grind and makes existence a lot more managable.
  • Much of the beauty found in the universe has its roots in the impermanent nature of things.
  • There is a difference between logic and rhetoric.
  • You can understand another's behavior without agreeing with it.
  • Debates at 10PM with good friends whlie eating greasy food when you have other work that needs to be done is the stuff of life.
  • While fate does not exist, only a fool believes in coincidence. 
  • Taking time to do things that you love, while fulfilling, still takes time.
  • You can miss people that you choose to cut out of your life, but that doesn't mean the choice should not have been made.
  • Compassion is the most powerful weapon one can wield.
  • Family is a term that extends beyond blood ties.
  • Grief cannot be forced.  It has to be organic and honest.
  • At the end of the day, if you can laugh at yourself, look at yourself in the mirror and sleep soundly, you have lived a good life.

I feel like the universe has cheated me out of a lot of potentially amazing friendships.

So my belt test today was ridiculous...

Anomalies:
  • Jiyuwaza for 5th kyu is already an anomaly, but Jonathan-sensei decided to make it an actual jiyuwaza.  This essentially means, instead of him saying "Dean, tsuki; John, shomen-uchi; Nellie, ryoutedori," it was "the three of you, grab him/strike him however you choose." 
  • Jonathan-sensei likes to throw in an extra person during jiyuwaza to spice things up.  For me he threw in two...
  • Randori was done with my elbows pinned to my sides by a belt...
    • He threw Jeff into the fray with shomen-uchi... (Ikkyo was not an option because of the above)
      • solution: shomenuchi kokyunage
    • John was sent in with ryoutedori from behind... (forward throw didn't work, again because of the above)
      • solution: ushiro ryoutedori kokyunage
I'm quite aware that NONE of you (save Laura-chan and any aikidoka out there) had any idea what any of that meant...
